Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 09:32AM jeanette51 wrote: I think recuperation time is different for everyone.....I had bilateral (no recons) Feb. 26th and am still too sore to return to work.  Also, I was told prosthesis fitting cannot be done until six weeks from date of surgery.  The incisions need to heal and swelling needs to be minimal before they can measure, so I am still waiting for that.  You will find alot of great info on this site and many women who are in the same situation as you....believe me, you will never feel alone! Hopefully, you are able to see a surgeon soon.   Good Luck!!  Keep us posted!!
Posts.Title: confused about HER2+ and ER+ flyrzfan jeanette51

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 09:55AM jeanette51 wrote: Hi ShariAnn,  I too have gone through chemo before surgery.  I did not start out that way.  I had a lumpectomy in August with no clear margins, SNB showed 2 out of 3 nodes positive.  Was sent to oncologist who thought it best to start chemo immediately to shrink what was left.  Finished chemo in January.....had bilateral Feb. 26th. Pathology came back clear....0/13 nodes, both breasts benign...therefore, chemo saved my life!!  How was your first treatment?  It is a rough cycle of treatments, but you can do it!  Stay strong and hang in there!!!
Posts.Title: Chemo before Masectomy? ShariAnn jdash

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 09:45AM jeanette51 wrote: I was also wondering what is involved in getting rid of the dogears...the nurse practitioner at my surgeon's office said they like to wait a year or so before doing anything with them.  I am only six weeks out from my surgery.  I really would hate to have to go back in for a hospital stay....any others have them removed as an outpatient?

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 06:31AM jeanette51 wrote: Hi Sue......please let me know if you had your surgery and how you are doing.  My chemo (Taxotere) will end the 23rd of January and my oncologist said she would like me to have surgery approx. four weeks later???  It does seem kinda soon.  Also, since I've only had one session of Taxotere so far, can you give me any suggestions?  I have experienced tightness in my chest, extremely tired, my nails hurt and of course, the usual.....nothing tastes right!! Let me know status of your surgery.....hope all went well! Jeanette

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 09:48AM jeanette51 wrote: Thanks to all who responded.....GREAT INFO!!   I am glad that I'm not alone out there!  It really amazes me when I realize how many of us are fighting this battle!  Thanks again to all my bc sisters!!
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy - PAIN jeanette51 dlm425

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 10:32AM jeanette51 wrote: Hi Jim, so sorry you and your wife are going through this.  I have a very similar story.  I was diagnosed in 7/07 and was due for a lumpectomy 8/7.  A few days before my lumpectomy, they did an MRI, which showed an additional area of suspicion.  My surgeon decided to continue with plans for lumpectomy hoping that she could still get it all.  Turns out, I had a cluster in my RT breast so they decided to start chemo before going back in to do more surgery.  Luckily, the chemo shrunk the masses; however, I was still advised to have a mastectomy.  I guess they needed to be sure they removed it all.  That was 2/26/08 and I am now cancer free.  As difficult as chemo is....it saved my life.  Please make sure your wife knows all her options before making any decisions.  If the docs decide chemo is necessary, your wife will get through it.  Please give her lots of support.  Sounds like you are already!!  This is a great site for her....please encourage her to get involved.  We've all been there and are here for one another whenever needed.
Posts.Title: My wife just was diagnosed with IDC jn06 Labgal

Posts.Content: jeanette51 wrote: Hope I can get some suggestions....had bilateral mastectomy Feb. 26th with no reconstruction.  I had less pain the first few weeks than I do now.  There seems to be a lot of puffiness across my chest.  How long before that starts to go away? Am having a terrible time sleeping at night.  Just can't seem to get comfortable.  I had 13 nodes removed from my right side and am experiencing "cording".  For the past two weeks I have been seeing a physical therapist, which is very painful.  I believe she thinks I am "gumby".  Is it supposed to be that painful??  I have also been given exercises to do at home twice a day.  I will be returning to work on the 14th of April and am hoping that the soreness won't be as bad.  Radiation will begin about the same time which I am concerned with.  Please let me know how long it takes before the pain subsides and you start to feel comfortable again.  God bless all my bc sisters!!!  Dx 7/6/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, 0/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy - PAIN jeanette51 dlm425

Posts.Content: jeanette51 wrote: Will be having bi-lateral mastectomy at the end of February.  My last chemo will be next week with radiation following surgery.  I had a lumpectomy previously but margins were not clear so they decided to start chemo before any more surgery.   My surgeon and oncologist both want me to meet with plastic surgeon just to see what my options are so I have set up an appt. for next week.  I am having mixed feelings about going through with any type of reconstruction at this point (swaying more towards no reconstruction).  Anyone out there who can give me some advice, I would really appreciate it.  Thanks to all who responded previously under Breast Reconstruction topic from last week.  This is such a hard decision!!!   Jeanette Dx 7/6/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, 0/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
